lessonActivities.title: CAN ‚Äì Express Ability, Permission, Possibility, and More!
lessonActivities.content:
'Can' is one of the most commonly used modal verbs in English. It expresses ability or opportunity, permission, and possibility or impossibility.

Can functions:

  • Ability: I can ride a horse.
  • Opportunity: We can stay with my brother when we are in Paris.
  • Permission: She cannot stay out after 10 PM.
  • Request: Can you hand me the stapler?
  • Possibility: Any child can grow up to be president.

Learn how 'Can' changes in past and future tenses and when to shift to 'could' or 'be able to'.
examples: She can't swim, but she can dance. (current ability and limitation)
Can you help me? (polite request for help)
lessonActivities.tips: Apply 'can' when discussing skills you have in the present moment or what's generally feasible. When recalling past abilities, rely on 'could' for those you practiced repeatedly, or 'was able to' for achievements you accomplished a single time.

lessonActivities.title: COULD ‚Äì Past Ability, Polite Requests, and Possibilities!
lessonActivities.content:
'Could' helps you express things that might be true, abilities from your past, along with making thoughtful requests and offering suggestions. It also appears frequently in 'what-if' type sentences.

Could functions:

  • Past Ability: I could run ten miles in my twenties.
  • Possibility: Extreme rain could cause the river to flood the city.
  • Suggestions: You could see a movie or go out to dinner.
  • Polite Requests: Could I use your computer to email my boss?
  • Conditional: We could go on the trip if I didn't have to work this weekend.
examples: I could speak Chinese when I was a kid. (past ability)
Could you post this letter for me? (polite request)
It could be true ‚Äì who knows! (possibility)
lessonActivities.tips: Important: Never use 'could' for something you managed to do just one time in the past. Choose 'was able to' instead. For example, 'Yesterday, I was able to lift the couch' works better than 'I could lift the couch'.

lessonActivities.title: BE ABLE TO ‚Äì Flexible Format for Ability!
lessonActivities.content:
'Be able to' is used to express ability and often replaces 'can' in this function, especially when you need different tense forms.

Be able to functions and forms:

  • Present: He is able to deal with difficult customers.
  • Past: She was able to decipher the code. / I wasn't able to reach the top shelf.
  • Future: I will be able to speak Chinese by the time I finish my course.
  • One-time past abilities: With a sudden burst of adrenaline, he was able to lift the car off the child's leg.

'Be able to' provides flexibility for expressing ability in any tense, which 'can/could' cannot provide on their own.
examples: She's very clever. She was able to decipher the code.
I'm not able to reach the top shelf. It's too high for me.
The doctor will be able to understand what she was saying.
lessonActivities.tips: Lean on 'be able to' when 'can' or 'could' create grammatical problems, or when you require control over specific tenses these simpler forms can't handle.

lessonActivities.title: CAN vs COULD vs BE ABLE TO ‚Äì Key Differences!
lessonActivities.content:
Recognizing which form fits each situation is vital for writing correct English.

AspectCANCOULDBE ABLE TO
Present AbilityI can swim‚ÄìI am able to swim
Past General Ability‚ÄìI could swim as a child‚Äì
Past One-time Achievement‚ÄìNOT CorrectHe was able to lift the car
Future AbilityI can help tomorrow‚ÄìI will be able to help
Permission (Present)Can I borrow your pen?‚Äì‚Äì
Polite Request‚ÄìCould you help me?‚Äì
PossibilityAnyone can become richIt could be true‚Äì
examples: I can speak English now. (present skill) vs. I was able to speak English after one year of practice. (one-time past result)
She could play the violin as a child. (familiar past habit) vs. Yesterday, she was able to remember all the songs. (singular past achievement)
Can you help me? (direct request) vs. Could you help me? (respectful request)
functions: Distinguishing general ability from one-time achievements
lessonActivities.tips: REMEMBER THIS: Pick 'was/were able to' when you accomplished something a single time in the past. Reserve 'could' for describing abilities you carried with you regularly or general skills from your past.

lessonActivities.title: Important Comparison: 'Could Not' vs 'Might NOT'
lessonActivities.content:
Many English learners confuse these two negative forms, but they have very different meanings!

  • 'Could not' (couldn't) ‚Üí suggests that something is IMPOSSIBLE. It's definitely not possible.
  • 'Might not' ‚Üí suggests you DO NOT KNOW if something happens. It's uncertain.

Examples:

  • "Jack might not have the key." ‚Üí Maybe he does have it, maybe he doesn't. Uncertain.
  • "Jack couldn't have the key." ‚Üí It is impossible that he has the key. Definitely not.

This distinction is crucial for expressing certainty vs. uncertainty accurately.
examples: The shop couldn't be closed ‚Äì it's only 3 PM! (impossible; the shop is definitely open)
The shop might not be open ‚Äì it could be closed for lunch. (possible but uncertain)
You couldn't be serious! (impossible; you must be joking)
You might not be serious. (uncertain; maybe you are, maybe you aren't)
lessonActivities.tips: Don't mix these up: 'Couldn't' signals something cannot or definitely won't happen. 'Might not' reveals genuine uncertainty about whether something will occur.

writingActivities.question: Write 6‚Äì8 sentences about your personal abilities and limitations. Use 'can' and 'can't' (or 'cannot') for present abilities. Include at least 4 ability statements.
writingActivities.hint: Example: I can speak English fluently, but I can't speak Japanese.

writingActivities.question: Write about something you could do when you were younger. Use 'could' for past general ability. Write at least 5 sentences using 'could' and 'couldn't'.
writingActivities.hint: Example: When I was a child, I could run very fast, but I couldn't swim well.
sentenceStarters: When I was young, I could ___

writingActivities.question: Describe a time when you successfully accomplished something difficult (past one-time achievement). Use 'was/were able to' at least 4 times. Explain how you felt.
writingActivities.hint: Example: Yesterday, I was able to finish the project before the deadline. I was very proud!

writingActivities.question: Write 6‚Äì8 sentences asking for permission and making polite requests. Use 'Can I...?', 'Could I...?', 'Can you...?', and 'Could you...?' at least 3 times each.
writingActivities.hint: Example: Can I borrow your pen? Could you help me with this? Can I ask you something?

writingActivities.question: Write about your abilities in the future. Use 'will be able to' and 'won't be able to' at least 4 times to describe what you will or won't be able to do in 5 years.
writingActivities.hint: Example: In 5 years, I will be able to speak three languages fluently. I won't be able to do everything I want.
sentenceStarters: In the future, I will be able to ___
I probably won't be able to ___

writingActivities.question: Write a paragraph describing possibilities and impossibilities in a given situation. Use 'can', 'could', and 'can't' to express possibility and impossibility. Include at least 6 statements.
writingActivities.hint: Example: It could be raining outside, or it could be sunny. It can't be snowing in July!

writingActivities.question: Compare your present abilities with your past abilities. Use both 'can' (present) and 'could' (past) at least 4 times each. Explain the differences.
writingActivities.hint: Example: I can swim fast now, but when I was young, I could only swim slowly. I can drive a car now, but I couldn't drive 5 years ago.
sentenceStarters: I can ___ now, but I couldn't ___
She can ___ now, whereas she could only ___

writingActivities.question: Write about overcoming a challenge or difficulty. Use 'wasn't/weren't able to' at first, then 'was/were able to' for the success. Include at least 4 examples.
writingActivities.hint: Example: At first, I wasn't able to understand the concept, but after studying hard, I was able to master it.
sentenceStarters: At first, I wasn't able to ___
We weren't able to ___, but finally we were able to ___

writingActivities.question: Distinguish between 'couldn't' (impossible) and 'might not' (uncertain) in your writing. Write at least 4 sentences using each form to show the difference in meaning.
writingActivities.hint: Example: He couldn't be home now ‚Äì it's only 9 AM! vs. He might not be home now ‚Äì he could be at work.

writingActivities.question: Free writing: Write a story or scenario using all three forms (can, could, be able to) naturally. Include present abilities, past abilities, and future possibilities. Aim for at least 10 sentences.
writingActivities.hint: Mix various contexts: present abilities, past memories, future plans, permissions, requests, and possibilities.

quizActivities.question: What does 'can' express in the present?
quizActivities.hint: When describing your current skills, choose 'can'.
quizActivities.explanation: To talk about talents and skills you possess right now, 'can' is your choice. Saying 'I can speak three languages' communicates your present-day proficiency.

quizActivities.question: When should you use 'was able to' instead of 'could'?
quizActivities.sentence: With great effort, he ____ lift the heavy box yesterday.
quizActivities.hint: 'Could' covers habits you had before; 'was able to' covers single accomplishments.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Could' only fits when you're talking about skills from your past that happened regularly. When you managed something just once, 'was able to' is correct. For yesterday's couch-lifting achievement, say 'was able to' not 'could'.

quizActivities.question: Which form makes this request MOST polite?
quizActivities.hint: 'Could' feels gentler and more respectful than the direct nature of 'can'.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Could' has a softer, more thoughtful quality compared to 'can', which comes off as straightforward. Phrasing your request as 'Could you help me?' shows more respect than 'Can you help me?'

quizActivities.question: What is the key difference between 'couldn't' and 'might not'?
quizActivities.sentence: The store ____ be closed - it's only noon!
quizActivities.hint: When something is ruled out, use 'couldn't'. When you're simply unsure, use 'might not'.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Couldn't' tells us something is ruled out or cannot be true. 'Might not' means you don't have enough info to decide. A store definitely has to be open at noon, so it 'couldn't' be closed.

quizActivities.question: How do you express repeated past ability?
quizActivities.sentence: When I was young, I ____ run very fast.
quizActivities.hint: 'Could' describes habitual or repeated abilities in the past, like general skills you had as a child.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Could' is used for repeated past abilities‚Äîskills or talents you had regularly. 'I could run fast' means this was a general ability in childhood.

quizActivities.question: What verb form expresses future ability?
quizActivities.sentence: After this training, I ____ perform the task professionally.
quizActivities.hint: 'Be able to' provides flexibility for future tenses. 'Will be able to' = future capability.
quizActivities.explanation: For future ability, use 'will be able to'. This form bridges the gap where 'can' doesn't naturally work in future contexts.

quizActivities.question: Which form shows present permission?
quizActivities.hint: 'Can' is used for asking permission in present situations ('Can I borrow your pen?').
quizActivities.explanation: 'Can' is the standard form for requesting or granting permission in the present. 'Can I leave early?' is the natural way to ask.

quizActivities.question: What expresses possibility or speculation?
quizActivities.sentence: That parcel ____ be for me ‚Äì I'm expecting one.
quizActivities.hint: 'Could' expresses possibility or things that might be true but you're not certain.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Could' is used for speculation and possibility. 'Could be' suggests it's possible but uncertain. Different from 'must be' (certainty) or 'will be' (plan).

quizActivities.question: How do you express inability in the past?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ understand the concept at first.
quizActivities.hint: 'Couldn't' expresses inability or lack of ability in the past period.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Couldn't' shows lack of ability in the past. 'I couldn't understand' = I lacked the ability to understand at that time.

quizActivities.question: Which correctly compares present and past abilities?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ speak English now, but when I was young, I ____ speak only my native language.
quizActivities.hint: Present: 'can'. Past repeated ability: 'could'. Use present tense for now.
quizActivities.explanation: Use 'can' for present abilities and 'could' for past habitual abilities. This shows the contrast between current and historical capability.
